Pioneer Permitting Experiences.

1. What led you to the particular district in which you settled? Location of relative, or method used.

What was the extent of this information and what alternatives did you consider?

He wrote in law 1909, claiming through land entry was open through land entry for the S.E. 1/4 of T2-25-21 W3.

II. Under what circumstances did you locate?

The land was owned by someone else.

2. What was your previous experience in farming?

Father had farmed on same 40 acres when he lived here and sold them to Mr. Smith for $100. He had no previous experience.

II. Under what circumstances did you locate?

The land was owned by someone else.

3. Did you homestead? No. Father did.

II. Give description of the land (township, range, distance from the railroad).

N.B. 9 1/2 miles from Alexandria, Ind.

Where, when, and how did you file your homestead entry?

I believe it was at Dayton, Ind.

How much information did you have about the land when you claimed your entry?

160 acres of land and all rights for $10.00 entry fee paid.

4. Did you obtain a pre-emption? He did not.

S.E. 18 off road 35 - R. 20 W3.

5. What other land did you purchase? The purchased S.W. N.W. N.1/4 of 7.

S.E. 18 all on road 25 - R. 20 W3.

6. Was any of it Homestead Entry Company Land? G. P. H. Land, or school land?

No.

S.W. N.W. N.W. 7-25-20 W3 - purchased from Mrs. Pearson Land Co.

What was the purchase price per acre? S.E. 18 - 25-20 W3 - 30.5

S.W. N.W. N.W. 7-25-20 W3 - 75 per acre (rail)

What was the largest amount you possessed at one time? (Give dates)

Father held 5 quarters (800 acres) overall (1914)

and a quarter under pasture lease.
